channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SPR-2524] Autowire byType very broken
item.description:
Could be tough to make a unit test out of, but the gist of it is that, when using autowire=byType, I've been seeing that Spring will actually get very confused and do one or all of the following:

  • Create an instance of a singleton bean many times (for example - we've seen it create the Quartz bean 7 times, resulting in 70 threads spread across 7 thread pools)
  • Fail to initialize a bean, such as the iBatis integration bean, but then not report the problem in the logs and instead just continue along without wiring up the SqlClientMap

If I set autowire=no and then do it by hand for each bean, the problem goes away. Or, as I did in my case, I just rolled back to 2.0 M2 and everything was fine.

Rolling back to 2.0 M2 fixed the problem just fine, so there is something definitely up with the release.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Thanks for pointing this out, Patrick. We generally try to strengthen the bean initialization contracts in Spring 2.0, to guarantee a correct result in all cases. Spring 1.2 sometimes comes up with a different result according to the initialization order, for example in terms of what's auto-proxied at what's not. Still, we of course do not want very expensive recreation and destruction going on; I did some tests that verified reports indicating a large number of attempts even for a small number of bean definitions.

Hence, I've reworked the FactoryBean type check mechanism substantially: For a plain type check, we instantiate the FactoryBean but not do not populate it yet, then try whether its <code>getObjectType</code> method already returns a type. If no type found, a full FactoryBean creation is used as fallback. Of course, a plain instance of such a FactoryBean is kept around until the FactoryBean is fully created, to avoid creating another instance for the live variant of the FactoryBean.

This means that beans like a Quartz SchedulerFactoryBean or Hibernate LocalSessionFactoryBean will not be fully created just for a type check anymore, and subsequently not destroyed if the creation attempt failed. Such a scenario can only arise with a FactoryBean that relies on constructor arguments now (expecting bean references there); however, this is rare - almost all FactoryBeans use setter injection (all the ones shipped with Spring do).

Juergen

Patrick, please give this a try with an nightly snapshot if you have the chance! It would be good to double-check this before the 2.0 final release.

Juergen
